name: %ABORT
description: Stops the macro that is executing along with the current DATA step, SAS job, or Compute Server.

arguments.name: ABEND
arguments.description:
causes abnormal termination of the current macro and SAS job. For the Compute Server, the SAS compute session is terminated. An abnormal error code is reflected in the sessionConditionCode. The session state is marked as canceled. Results depend on the method of operation:
• batch mode and non-interactive mode.  
• stops processing immediately.
• sends an error message to the SAS log that states that execution was terminated by the ABEND option of the %ABORT macro statement.
• does not execute any subsequent statements or check syntax.
• returns control to the operating environment. Further action is based on how your operating environment and your site treat jobs that end abnormally.
• interactive line mode.  
• causes your macro interactive line mode to stop processing immediately and return you to your operating environment.

arguments.name: CANCEL
arguments.description: causes the cancellation of the current submitted statements. The results depend on the method of operation.

arguments.name: FILE
arguments.description: when coded as an option to the CANCEL argument in an autoexec file or in a %INCLUDE file, causes only the contents of the autoexec file or %INCLUDE file to be cleared by the %ABORT statement. Other submitted source statements will be executed after the autoexec or %INCLUDE file.

arguments.name: RETURN
arguments.description:
causes abnormal termination of the current macro and SAS job or session. For the Compute Server, the SAS compute session is terminated. An abnormal error code is reflected in the sessionConditionCode. The session state is marked as canceled. Results depend on the method of operation:
• batch mode and non-interactive mode  
• stops processing immediately
• sends an error message to the SAS log that states that execution was terminated by the RETURN option of the %ABORT macro statement
• does not execute any subsequent statements or check syntax
• returns control to the operating environment with a condition code indicating an error
•  interactive line mode  
• causes your macro and interactive line mode to stop processing immediately and return you to your operating environment

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: an integer value that enables you to specify a condition code: • When used with the CANCEL argument, the value is placed in the SYSINFO automatic macro variable. • When it is NOT used with the CANCEL statement, SAS returns the value to the operating environment when the execution stops. The range of values for n depends on your operating environment.

name: %COLORMAC
description: creates the color utility macros in the current SAS session.

name: %COPY
description: Copies specified items from a SAS macro library.

arguments.name: macro-name
arguments.description: name of the macro that the %COPY statement will use.

arguments.name: LIBRARY=
arguments.description: specifies the libref of a SAS library that contains a catalog of stored compiled SAS macros. If no library is specified, the libref specified by the SASMSTORE= option is used.

arguments.name: OUTFILE=
arguments.description: specifies the output destination of the %COPY statement. The value can be a fileref or an external file.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: specifies that the source code of the macro will be copied to the output destination. If the OUTFILE= option is not specified, the source is written to the SAS log.

name: %DO
description: Begins a %DO group.

name: %END
description: Ends a %DO group.

name: %GLOBAL
description: Creates macro variables that are available during the execution of an entire Compute Server session.

arguments.name: macro-variable
arguments.description: is the name of one or more macro variables or a text expression that generates one or more macro variable names. You cannot use a SAS variable list or a macro expression that generates a SAS variable list in a %GLOBAL statement.

arguments.name: READONLY
arguments.description: creates a new read only global macro variable.

arguments.name: macro-variable
arguments.description: is the name of a macro variable or a text expression that produces a macro variable name. The name must be a new macro variable name.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: is a character string or a text expression.

name: %GOTO
description: Branches macro processing to the specified label.

arguments.name: label
arguments.description: is either the name of the label that you want execution to branch to or a text expression that generates the label. A text expression that generates a label in a %GOTO statement is called a computed %GOTO destination.A computed %GOTO contains % or & and resolves to a label.

name: %HELPCLR
description: writes Help information about the color utility macros to the SAS log.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: writes a short description and an example for each of the color utility macros to the SAS log.

arguments.name: macro-name
arguments.description: writes a short description and an example for the specified color utility macro to the SAS log. Do not include the percent sign (%) in macro-name.

name: %IF-%THEN/%ELSE
description: Conditionally process a portion of a macro.

arguments.name: %IF
arguments.description: is any macro expression that resolves to an integer. If the expression resolves to an integer other than zero, the expression is true and the %THEN clause is processed. If the expression resolves to zero, then the expression is false and the %ELSE statement, if one is present, is processed. If the expression resolves to a null value or a value containing nonnumeric characters, the macro processor issues an error message. For more information about writing macro expressions and their evaluation, see .

arguments.name: %THEN
arguments.description: is either constant text, a text expression, or a macro statement. If action contains semicolons (for example, in SAS statements), then the first semicolon after %THEN ends the %THEN clause. Use a %DO group or a quoting function, such as %STR, to prevent semicolons in action from ending the %IF-%THEN statement. The following examples show two ways to conditionally generate text that contains semicolons:

name: %INPUT
description: Supplies values to macro variables during macro execution.

arguments.name: no
arguments.description: specifies that all text entered is assigned to the automatic macro variable SYSBUFFR.

arguments.name: macro-variable
arguments.description: is the name of a macro variable or a macro text expression that produces a macro variable name. The %INPUT statement can contain any number of variable names separated by blanks.

name: %LET
description: Creates a macro variable and assigns it a value.

arguments.name: macro-variable
arguments.description: is either the name of a macro variable or a text expression that produces a macro variable name. The name can refer to a new or existing macro variable.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: is a character string or a text expression. Omitting value produces a null value (0 characters). Leading and trailing blanks in value are ignored. To make them significant, enclose value with the %STR function.

name: %LOCAL
description: Creates macro variables that are available only during the execution of the macro where they are defined.

arguments.name: macro-variable
arguments.description: is the name of one or more macro variables or a text expression that generates one or more macro variable names. You cannot use a SAS variable list or a macro expression that generates a SAS variable list in a %LOCAL statement.

arguments.name: READONLY
arguments.description: creates a new read-only local macro variable.

arguments.name: macro-variable
arguments.description: is the name of a macro variable or a text expression that produces a macro variable name.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: is a character string or a text expression.

name: %MACRO
description: Begins a macro definition.

arguments.name: macro-name
arguments.description: names the macro. A macro name must be a SAS name, which you supply; you cannot use a text expression to generate a macro name in a %MACRO statement. In addition, do not use macro reserved words as a macro name. (For a list of macro reserved words, see .)

arguments.name: parameters
CMD
arguments.description: specifies that the macro can accept either a name-style invocation or a command-style invocation. Macros defined with the CMD option are sometimes called command-style macros.

arguments.name: DES=
arguments.description: specifies a description for the macro entry in the macro catalog. The description text can be up to 256 characters in length. Enclose the description in quotation marks. This description appears in the CATALOG window when you display the contents of the catalog containing the stored compiled macros. The DES= option is especially useful when you use the stored compiled macro facility.

arguments.name: MINDELIMITER=
arguments.description: specifies a value that will override the value of the MINDELIMITER= system option. The value must be a single character enclosed in single quotation marks and can appear only once in a %MACRO statement.

arguments.name: MINOPERATOR
arguments.description: specifies that the macro processor recognizes and evaluates the mnemonic IN and the special character # as logical operators when evaluating arithmetic or logical expressions during the execution of the macro. The setting of this argument overrides the setting of the NOMINOPERATOR global system option.

arguments.name: NOMINOPERATOR
arguments.description: specifies that the macro processor recognizes and evaluates the mnemonic IN and the special character # as logical operators when evaluating arithmetic or logical expressions during the execution of the macro. The setting of this argument overrides the setting of the NOMINOPERATOR global system option.

arguments.name: PARMBUFF
arguments.description: assigns the entire list of parameter values in a macro call, including the parentheses in a name-style invocation, as the value of the automatic macro variable SYSPBUFF. Using the PARMBUFF option, you can define a macro that accepts a varying number of parameter values.

arguments.name: SECURE
arguments.description: causes the contents of a macro to be encrypted when stored in a stored compiled macro library.

arguments.name: NOSECURE
arguments.description: causes the contents of a macro to be encrypted when stored in a stored compiled macro library.

arguments.name: STMT
arguments.description: specifies that the macro can accept either a name-style invocation or a statement-style invocation. Macros defined with the STMT option are sometimes called statement-style macros.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: combines and stores the source of the compiled macro with the compiled macro code as an entry in a SAS catalog in a permanent SAS library. The SOURCE option requires that the STORE option and the MSTORED option be set. You can use the SASMSTORE= option to identify a permanent SAS library. You can store a macro or call a stored compiled macro only when the MSTORED option is in effect. (For more information, see .)

arguments.name: SRC
arguments.description: combines and stores the source of the compiled macro with the compiled macro code as an entry in a SAS catalog in a permanent SAS library. The SOURCE option requires that the STORE option and the MSTORED option be set. You can use the SASMSTORE= option to identify a permanent SAS library. You can store a macro or call a stored compiled macro only when the MSTORED option is in effect. (For more information, see .)

arguments.name: STORE
arguments.description: stores the compiled macro as an entry in a SAS catalog in a permanent SAS library. Use the SAS system option SASMSTORE= to identify a permanent SAS library. You can store a macro or call a stored compiled macro only when the SAS system option MSTORED is in effect. (For more information, see .)

name: %MEND
description: Ends a macro definition.

arguments.name: macro-name
arguments.description: names the macro as it ends a macro definition. Repeating the name of the macro is optional, but it is useful for clarity. If you specify macro-name, the name in the %MEND statement should match the name in the %MACRO statement; otherwise, SAS issues a warning message.

name: %PUT
description: Writes text or macro variable information to the SAS log.

arguments.name: text
arguments.description: specifies text that is written to the SAS log. Text can be literal text or a text expresson. If text is longer than the current line size, the remainder of the text appears on the next line. The %PUT statement removes leading and trailing blanks from text unless you use a macro quoting function.

arguments.name: ERROR:
arguments.description: specifies an error message, which is displayed in red text in the SAS log.

arguments.name: ERROR-
arguments.description: specifies an additional line of text for an error message.

arguments.name: NOTE:
arguments.description: specifies a note, which is displayed in blue text in the SAS log.

arguments.name: NOTE-
arguments.description: specifies an additional line of text for a note.

arguments.name: WARNING:
arguments.description: specifies a warning message, which is displayed in green text in the SAS log.

arguments.name: WARNING-
arguments.description: specifies an additional line of text for a warning message.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: lists the values of all user-generated and automatic macro variables.

arguments.name: _AUTOMATIC_
arguments.description: lists the values of automatic macro variables. The automatic variables listed depend on the SAS products installed at your site and on your operating system. The scope is identified as AUTOMATIC.

arguments.name: _GLOBAL_
arguments.description: lists user-generated global macro variables. The scope is identified as GLOBAL.

arguments.name: _LOCAL_
arguments.description: lists user-generated local macro variables. The scope is the name of the currently executing macro.

arguments.name: _READONLY_
arguments.description: lists all user-defined read-only macro variables, regardless of scope. The scope is either GLOBAL, for global macro variables, or the name of the macro in which the macro variable is defined.

arguments.name: _USER_
arguments.description: lists user-generated global and local macro variables. The scope is identified either as GLOBAL, or as the name of the macro in which the macro variable is defined.

arguments.name: _WRITABLE_
arguments.description: lists all user-defined read and write macro variables, regardless of scope. The scope is either GLOBAL, for global macro variables, or the name of the macro in which the macro variable is defined.

name: %RETURN
description: Execution causes normal termination of the currently executing macro.

name: %SYMDEL
description: Deletes the specified variable or variables from the macro global symbol table.

arguments.name: macro-variable
arguments.description: is the name of one or more macro variables or a text expression that generates one or more macro variable names. You cannot use a SAS variable list or a macro expression that generates a SAS variable list in a %SYMDEL statement.

arguments.name: NOWARN
arguments.description: suppresses the warning message when an attempt is made to delete a non-existent macro variable.

name: %SYSCALL
description: Invokes a SAS call routine.

arguments.name: call-routine
arguments.description: is a SAS or user-written CALL routine created with SAS/TOOLKIT software or a routine created using . All SAS CALL routines are accessible with %SYSCALL except LABEL, VNAME, SYMPUT, and EXECUTE.

arguments.name: call-routine-argument
arguments.description: is one or more macro variable names (with no leading ampersands), separated by commas. You can use a text expression to generate part or all of the CALL routine arguments.

name: %SYSEXEC
description: Executes Linux commands.

arguments.name: no
arguments.description: starts a new Linux shell, where you can issue Linux commands and return to your Compute Server session.

arguments.name: command
arguments.description: is any Linux command. If command contains a semicolon, use a macro quoting function.

name: %SYSLPUT
description: Creates a new macro variable or modifies the value of an existing macro variable on a remote host or server.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: is a macro variable reference, a macro invocation, or the character value to be assigned to the server macro-variable.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: copies all user-generated and automatic macro variables to the server session.

arguments.name: _AUTOMATIC_
arguments.description: copies all automatic macro variables to the server session.

arguments.name: _GLOBAL_
arguments.description: copies all user-generated global macro variables to the server session.

arguments.name: _LOCAL_
arguments.description: copies all user-generated local macro variables to the server session.

arguments.name: _USER_
arguments.description: pushes all user-defined macro variables from the local host to the remote host or server all at the same time.

arguments.name: REMOTE=
arguments.description: specfies the name of the server session that the macro variable will be created in.

arguments.name: LIKE=
arguments.description: specifies a sequence of characters, or pattern, to be used as the criteria for determining which macro variables are to be copied to the server session.

name: %SYSMACDELETE
description: Deletes a macro definition from the Work.SASMacr catalog.

arguments.name: macro_name
arguments.description: the name of a macro or a text expression that produces a macro variable name.

arguments.name: NOWARN
arguments.description: specifies that no warning diagnostic message should be issued.

name: %SYSMSTORECLEAR
description: Closes the stored compiled macro catalog associated with the libref specified in the SASMSTORE= option.

name: %SYSRPUT
description: Assigns a value from the remote host to a macro variable on the local host.

arguments.name: local-macro-variable
arguments.description: is the name of a macro variable with no leading ampersand or a text expression that produces the name of a macro variable. This name must be a macro variable that is stored on the local host.

arguments.name: remote-macro-variable
arguments.description: is the name of a macro variable with the leading ampersand or a text expression that produces the name of a macro variable with the leading ampersand. This name must be a macro variable that is stored on a remote host.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: is a value or an expression that produces a value.

arguments.name: _USER_
arguments.description: to push all remote user-defined macro variables from the remote host to the local host all at the same time.

arguments.name: LIKE=
arguments.description:
Specifies the sequence of characters, or pattern, to be used as the criteria for determining which macro variables are to be copied to the server session. Character patterns can consist of the following:
• any sequence of characters, A–Z
• any sequence of digits, 0–9
• a single wildcard character in the form of an asterisk (*)
